data.title: Save dialog whilst open multiple tabs of the same file
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

If I have open multiple tabs of the same file and want to close one VS Code forces me with a modal to decide if I want to save the file. Wouldn't it be sufficient if it just asks if someone wants to close the last tab of this file?

See here:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2873986/18271432/48759582-7432-11e6-94da-48c827c0295c.png)

data.title: Find with mult-line is not giving correct results if regex has beginning boundary
data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:
1. Consider a file with following text

```
if
else

if
else
```
1. Perform find with regex - `^if\nelse`

Expected: Two matches lines {1, 2} and {4,5}
Observed: Only one match line {1,2} is shown

data.title: Persist user choice in Find options (case, whole word, regex) in the Find widget in editor

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Mac OS El Capitan 10.11.4

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open VS Code and some file
2. Cmd+F to find something
3. Check the box to enable case-sensitivity and regex searching
4. Close VS Code
5. Open VS Code and some file again
6. Cmd+F to find something

Expected behavior: the boxes for case-sensitivity and regex searching are checked.

Actual behavior: the boxes for case-sensitivity and regex searching are unchecked.

I _always_ want to search with these options enabled. How can I persist this state across restarts?

data.title: Improve extension engine compatibility
data.body:
Currently, an extension is deemed **outdated** when there's a newer version published in the Marketplace. Installing an extension requires `O(published_versions)` request roundtrips: starting from the latest version, the engine field is checked for compatibility with the current Code, and it goes on backwards from there.

We should:
- [x] Publish extensions with the compatibility value as a property
- [x] Use that property to figure out which version to install
- [x] Use that property to correctly figure out whether the extension is outdated
## 

VSIX manifest format:

```
<Properties>
      <Property Id="abc" Value="def" />
      <Property Id="ghi" Value="jkl" />
</Properties>
```

Response:

``` json
"version": "0.1.15",
              "flags": "validated",
              "lastUpdated": "2016-09-06T04:41:03.74Z",
              "properties": [
                {
                  "key": "abc",
                  "value": "def"
                },
                {
                  "key": "ghi",
                  "value": "jkl"
                }
]
```

data.title: Regex find does not match on beginning and end of lines (missing multiline flag?)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Windows

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Search for regex including beginning or end of line matches. Examples:
   - `^\s*$\n` (should match empty lines)
   - `^A.*B$` (should match every line starting with A and ending with B (e.g. `A****************B`)
2. Expected: match
3. Actual: No match.

Ref. issue #313, which is closed, but in essense the same, or at least very similar.

Esp. @alexandrudima 's comment, stating that this might be to a missing multiline flag passed to the Javascript regex engine.

https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/313#issuecomment-244772017

data.title: Programs / executables / libraries are not signed
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.4.0 (6276dcb0ae497766056b4c09ea75be1d76a8b679, 2016-08-04T16:45:31.680Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Download and install VSCode
2. Open VSCode
3. Open Process Explorer
4. In Process Explorer, enable Verify Image Signatures from Options menu

Expected Results:

Verified Signer column says "(Verified) Microsoft Corporation"

Actual Results:

Verified Signer column says "(No signature was present in the subject) Microsoft Corporation"

More Details:

There are two particular processes running on my machine:
- C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft VS Code\Code.exe
- c:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft VS Code\resources\app\out\vs\workbench\services\files\node\watcher\win32\CodeHelper.exe

However, I'd expect all executable components to be signed, including libraries (currently only the MSVC runtime libraries are signed).

data.title: [Question] Is it possible to add debugging capabilities to other file types
data.body:
We have a VSCode extension for [Cake](http://cakebuild.net/) which extends VSCode with a few things, including snippets, commands, syntax highlighting etc.

We recently converted Cake to be built with .Net Core, which means that we have now been able to add debugging support within VSCode.  However, in order for this to work, we have to switch the configured language for the file, i.e. we have to change this:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1271146/18263632/8300bad0-7403-11e6-83d0-6c234cf8bbe6.png)

To this:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1271146/18263650/a1d36890-7403-11e6-9e85-983167e937b7.png)

via the dropdown list:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1271146/18263641/94c8638a-7403-11e6-81ea-0931bda8d77c.png)

However, in doing that, we then lose the configured snippets that we have configured.  Is there a way to enable the debugging experience for files to type `.cake` without first needing to switch to the `C#` language?  Thanks!

data.title: [Feature] Ability to parse build.cake files to auto create task definitions
data.body:
I asked the question on Twitter:

https://twitter.com/gep13/status/772878923243876352

And @egamma replied to say that there wasn't currently any extension points to allow extensions to provide additional automatic task definitions.  Instead, that the only point where this was possible was contained within this file:

https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/tasks/common/taskTemplates.ts

So, my question is, would a PR to extend this file to recognise build.cake files be accepted if I were to create one?  Also, I am assuming that I would need to extend the codebase with the ability to parse the build.cake file, but after a quick glance at the code, I couldn't see where that happened, could someone point me in the right direction?  Thanks!

data.title: Debug console recognizes DateTime as URL
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04 LTS

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Write a simple app in any language (I use C# with .NET Core) that writes current date time to console like `[9/6/16 11:33:45 AM]`
2. In Debug Console, part of the date time will be recognized as a URL.
3. Click the URL and it says `Unable to open '16 11': File not found (/6/16 11).`

This is not a big deal but can be nice to get fixed.

data.title: Linux build: Ubuntu Software Center complains "The package is of bad quality"
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4, master
- OS Version: Ubuntu 14.04

Steps to Reproduce:
1. run `gulp vscode-linux-x64-build-deb`
2. open `.build/linux/deb/amd64/deb/code-oss_1.5.0-1473128807_amd64.deb` (or whatever your tagged build result is) in your file chooser (ie, open in Nautilus, double click)
3. Wait for Ubuntu Software Center to open and show the package
4. Warning pops up: 
   ![screenshot from 2016-09-05 19 24 41](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/773184/18260123/bff51dd2-739f-11e6-8a8f-557c22cc9bbf.png)

I have fixed this, it's small, but opening the bug before the PR so I can reference this.

data.title: [themes] make color themes user configurable
data.body:
I really liked the last updates the team has made in order to improve Code even further, but one thing I do miss from Atom (since I switched to Code) is the ability to change the  syntax highlighter colors on the fly, we could just open the debug tools, look into the classes, then just finding them inside the less file and boom! We could change the way languages were colored inside the editor.

This is something that really annoys me because some languages simply do not have color support...

2. write something

4. try to close

data.title: Inverted (natural) scrolling on Linux?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu (Lubuntu flavor) 16.04 LTS 

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Swipe with two fingers upwards 
2. Window moves up instead of down, though I have natural scrolling enabled on Lubuntu

Could it be the reason that natural scrolling is not a default preference in Lubuntu? Is there a way to enable natural scrolling on VSCode, though? I use it everywhere, it feels unnatural to behave differently when I'm using the editor.

[This has been asked on SO before, as well.
](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/36835562/inverted-scrolling-natural-in-vscode)

data.title: As a user I want to be able to set the exception type for exception breakpoints
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: 10.11.5

Currently the exception breakpoint settings apply to all types of exceptions. In many languages such as Clojure/Java, there is a hierarchy of exception classes and it is convenient to only break on specific exception types. For instance if I see an exception caused by a ClassCastException I want to be able to set a breakpoint that will only trigger for ClassCastExceptions.

I think this would merely entail an input text box for typing the class to associate with a particular breakpoint, and this could be enabled only for debug adapters that report the capability to break on specific exception types.

data.title: JS Syntax highlighting breaks when creating new objects without parenthesis
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4
- OS Version: Win 10

Steps to Reproduce:

![untitled](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3441158/18254579/c2a55156-73bc-11e6-8e1d-db619cafd466.png)

It only happens if there's a closing parenthesis right after the class name.

so `var a = new Date;` is fine but `var a = (new Date);` is not. The function baz doesn't show it's green color. Not sure if this is a VS code issue or if there's some other repo for just language specific syntax highlighting.

- OS Version:

I am successfully tokenising an uncommon language and would like to do ctrl shift O to list functions.

I have

```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<!DOCTYPE plist PUBLIC "-//Apple//DTD PLIST 1.0//EN" "http://www.apple.com/DTDs/PropertyList-1.0.dtd">
<plist version="1.0">
<dict>
    <key>fileTypes</key>

        <string>et</string>
        <string>etfiles</string>
    </array>
    <key>name</key>
    <string>seecheck</string>
    <key>patterns</key>
    <array>
        <dict>
            <key>match</key>
        <string>\b(accept|add|alert|back|bypass|clear|clearoff|close|current|declare|delete|divide|execute|external|filestatus|fill|flag|forward|get current|get first|get last|get next|get prior|get|gives|idxmode|
            include|includex|input|insert|journal|length|lfilestatus|link|load|move|multiply|open|output|pause|position|protect|refresh|release|remove|restore|save|set|setnormal|setupper|show|size|sort|
            store|subtract|sync|system|textfile|to|type|using|when batch|when correct|when not correct|when entry|when not entry|when eot|when examine|when not examine|when field|when not field|when file|when flag|when not flag|
                when fmt|when not fmt|when interrupt|when lock|when not lock|when overflow|when ree|when resume|when not resume|when start|when terminate|when verify|when not verify)\b</string>
            <key>name</key>
            <string>keyword.other.seecheck</string>
        </dict>
        <dict>
            <key>match</key>
        <string>\b(goto|else|enter|exit|if|jump|perform|stop|wait)\b</string>
            <key>name</key>
            <string>keyword.control.seecheck</string>
        </dict>
        <dict>
            <key>begin</key>
            <string>"</string>
            <key>end</key>
            <string>"</string>
            <key>name</key>
            <string>string.quoted.double.seecheck.seecheck</string>
        </dict>
        <dict>
            <key>begin</key>
            <string>'</string>
            <key>end</key>
            <string>'</string>
            <key>name</key>
            <string>string.quoted.single.seecheck.seecheck</string>
        </dict>
        <dict>
            <key>match</key>
        <string>\$var[0-9][0-9]</string>
            <key>name</key>
            <string>variable.other.seecheck</string>
        </dict>
        <dict>
            <key>begin</key>
            <string>note</string>
            <key>end</key>
            <string>\.</string>
            <key>name</key>
            <string>comment.block.seecheck</string>
        </dict>
        <dict>
            <key>begin</key>
            <string>\[\*</string>
            <key>end</key>
            <string>\*\]</string>
            <key>name</key>
            <string>comment.block.seecheck</string>
        </dict>
        <dict>
            <key>match</key>
            <string>!\w*</string>
            <key>name</key>
            <string>entity.name.tag.seecheck</string>
        </dict>
    </array>
    <key>scopeName</key>
    <string>source.seecheck</string>
    <key>uuid</key>
    <string>EF1825E8-6B1C-11D9-B883-000D93589AF6</string>
</dict>
</plist>
```

In my syntaxes folder

And I added this to a Preferences folder I created but I think its the wrong way.
Any hints on how to do this.

```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<!DOCTYPE plist PUBLIC "-//Apple//DTD PLIST 1.0//EN" "http://www.apple.com/DTDs/PropertyList-1.0.dtd">
```
